Grid#

Functions about grids

jrystal._src.grid.cubic_mask(grid_sizes: List | Array) → Bool[Array, '... n1 n2 n3']#

Get a cubic fft frequency mask such that it enables only part of the frequencies. Since the density \(\rho\) is the absolute square of the wave function \(\psi\), therefore \(\rho\) contains more frequency components, as the components in \(\psi\) are combined.

Read more on 1. Why / How to mask the frequency components.

Parameters:

grid_sizes – grid sizes (x y z) of the 3D reciprocal frequency.

Returns:

A 3D frequency mask.

jrystal._src.grid.estimate_max_cutoff_energy(cell_vectors: Float[Array, '3 3'], mask: Bool[Array, '... n1 n2 n3']) → float#

Estimate the maximum of cutoff energy of a cubic mask.

Parameters:

  • cell_vectors (CellVector) – cell vectors.

  • mask (ScalarGrid[Bool, 3]) – a cubic mask. can also be any frequency mask.

Returns:

the maximum cutoff energy corresponding to the input mask.

jrystal._src.grid.g2cell_vectors(g_vector_grid: Float[Array, '*nd d']) → Float[Array, '3 3']#

Transform the G vector grid to cell vectors.

Parameters:

g_vector_grid (Float[Array, “*nd d”]) – the G vector grid.

Returns:

the cell vectors.

Return type:

CellVector

jrystal._src.grid.g2r_vector_grid(g_vector_grid: Float[Array, '*nd d'], cell_vectors: Float[Array, '3 3']) → Float[Array, '*nd d']#

Transform the G vector grid (reciprocal space) to R vector grid.

Parameters:

  • g_vector_grid (Float[Array, “*nd d”]) – the G vector grid.

  • cell_vectors (CellVector) – the cell vectors.

Returns:

the R vector grid.

Return type:

Float[Array, “*nd d”]

jrystal._src.grid.g_vectors(cell_vectors, grid_sizes) → Float[Array, '... n1 n2 n3 3']#

Given the lattice vector of the unit cell, and grid size on each axis, return the G vectors in the recirpocal space.

We denote cell_vectors as \(\boldsymbol{a}\), reciprocal vector as \(\boldsymbol{b}\). In 3D,

\[\begin{split}&G_{ijk} = (i\boldsymbol{b}_1 + j\boldsymbol{b}_2 + k\boldsymbol{b}_3) \\ &i \in [0, n_i-1], j \in [0, n_j-1], k \in [0, n_k-1]\end{split}\]
Parameters:

  • cell_vectors – real space lattice vectors for the the unit cell. A (d, d) matrix if the spatial dimension is d. d is usually 3

  • grid_sizes – number of grid points along each axis.

Returns:

a tensor with shape (*grid_sizes, d).

Return type:

jnp.ndarray

jrystal._src.grid.grid_vector_radius(grid_vector: Float[Array, '*n d'])#

get the radius of grid vectors.

Parameters:

grid_vector (VectorField) – a input vector field. the first seveval dimensions can be any batch dimension.

jrystal._src.grid.k_vectors(cell_vectors: Float[Array, '3 3'], grid_sizes: Int[Array, '...']) → Float[Array, 'nkpts 3']#

Construct a uniform sampling of k-space of given size with Monkhorst-Pack scheme.

Parameters:

  • cell_vectors – cell vectors of shape (3, 3).

  • grid_sizes – (x y z).

Returns:

k-vectors.

Return type:

Float[Array, ‘nkpts 3’]

jrystal._src.grid.proper_grid_size(grid_sizes: Int | Int[Array, 'd'] | Tuple | List) → Array#

Get proper grid_sizes which is an numpy array, the grid size are good fftw factors.

Parameters:

  • grid_sizes (Int | Array | Tuple | List) – grid size. can be either list,

  • tuple

  • the (numpy.array or scalar. A scalar indicates that all)

  • size. (dimensions have the same grid)

Returns:

a numpy array indicates the grid size on each dimension.

Return type:

Array

jrystal._src.grid.r2g_vector_grid(r_vector_grid: Float[Array, '*nd d'], cell_vectors: Float[Array, '3 3']) → Float[Array, '*nd d']#

Transform the R vector grid to G vector grid.

Parameters:

  • r_vector_grid (Float[Array, “*nd d”]) – the R vector grid.

  • cell_vectors (CellVector) – the cell vectors.

Returns:

the G vector grid.

Return type:

Float[Array, “*nd d”]

jrystal._src.grid.r_vectors(cell_vectors, grid_sizes) → Float[Array, '... n1 n2 n3 3']#

Given the lattice vector of the unit cell, and grid size on each axis, return the R vectors in the real space.

We denote cell_vectors as \(\boldsymbol{a}\), reciprocal vector as \(\boldsymbol{b}\). In 3D,

\[\begin{split}&R_{ijk} = \frac{i}{n_i}\boldsymbol{a}_1 + \frac{j}{n_j}\boldsymbol{a}_2 + \frac{k}{n_k}\boldsymbol{a}_3 \\ &i \in [0, n_i-1], j \in [0, n_j-1], k \in [0, n_k-1]\end{split}\]
Parameters:

  • cell_vectors – real space lattice vectors for the the unit cell. A (d, d) matrix if the spatial dimension is d. d is usually 3.

  • grid_sizes – number of grid points along each axis.

Returns:

a tensor with shape (*grid_sizes, d).

Return type:

jnp.ndarray

jrystal._src.grid.spherical_mask(cell_vectors: Float[Array, '3 3'], grid_sizes: List | Array, cutoff_energy: float) → Bool[Array, '... n1 n2 n3']#

Get a spherical fft frequency mask such that

\[\frac{\|G\|^2}{2} \leq \text{cutoff}\]

holds for all \(G\).

Parameters:

  • cell_vectors – cell vectors

  • grid_sizes – grid sizes (x y z) of the 3D reciprocal frequency.

  • cutoff_energy – cutoff energy of the frequencies.

Returns:

A 3D frequency mask.

jrystal._src.grid.translation_vectors(cell_vectors: Float[Array, '3 3'], cutoff: Float[Array, '3'] | float = 10000.0) → Float[Array, 'num 3']#

Construct the translation grid lattice for ewald sum.

Parameters:

  • cell_vectors (ndarray) – the reciprocal vectors

  • cutoff (ndarray) – the real space cutoff such that 1/cutoff ~ 0. The larger the more precise of ewald sum.

Returns:

(nt, 3)

Return type:

The translation grid lattice, shape

previous

Ewald

next

Hamiltonian
